questiontext.text: In times of rising prices, the FIFO method of inventory valuation, when compared to the average cost method of inventory valuation, will usually result in which of the following?

generalfeedback.text: Lower-valued inventory has been used in production and higher-valued inventory remains on hand.

answer.text: A higher profit and a lower closing inventory value
A higher profit and a higher closing inventory value
A lower profit and a lower closing inventory value
A lower profit and a higher closing inventory value

questiontext.text:
Peter discovered that goods with a cost of $5,000 and a net realisable value of $3,000 have been omitted from the year-end inventory count.
What adjustment should be made to closing inventory?

generalfeedback.text: The inventory has been omitted, and must be included at its net realisable value of $3,000.

questiontext.text:
Lavender measured her inventory at 31 December 20X2 at its cost of $11,480. This included some items which cost $975 which have been hard to sell. Lavender intends to have these items repacked at a cost of $225. This will allow her to sell them for $450.
What was the correct value of closing inventory at 31 December 20X2?

Answer: {2:NUMERICAL:=10730:0}

generalfeedback.text:
The hard to sell items have a net realisable value of $450 - $225 = $225
So, the value of the closing inventory should have been:
Original$11,480
Less hard to sell inventory at cost(975)
Add NRV225
Closing inventory at 31 December 20X2$10,730

questiontext.text: Which of the following is the correct formula to calculate cost of sales?

Timmy has recently commenced trading. The materials he uses in his business are subject to regular price rises. He is unsure how to value his inventory and is trying to decide whether to use first in, first out (FIFO), or continuous weighted average.
Which of the following statements is correct?

generalfeedback.text: FIFO will lead to higher reported profit because his cost of sales will be based on the earliest (and therefore cheapest) purchases

answer.text: Timmy's profit will be unaffected by the method of inventory valuation.
FIFO will lead to a higher reported profit.
Continuous weighted average will lead to a higher reported profit.
The profit figure will be more accurate if FIFO is used.

questiontext.text:
Monica sold some items of inventory for $1,950 in cash which she had bought for $2,622.
How are her assets and capital affected by the sale?

generalfeedback.text:
Assets: Reduced by $672; Capital: Reduced by $672
One asset recorded at $2,622 (inventory) has been exchanged for another asset worth $1,950.
Therefore, both assets and capital are reduced by the difference of $672 ($2,622 – $1,950).

questiontext.text:
A firm has the following transactions with its product R.
1 January 20X1 Opening inventory: nil
1 February 20X1 Buys 10 units at $300 per unit
11 February 20X1 Buys 12 units at $250 per unit
1 April 20X1 Sells 8 units at $400 per unit
1 August 20X1 Buys 6 units at $200 per unit
1 December 20X1 Sells 12 units at $400 per unit
The firm uses periodic weighted average cost (AVCO) to value its inventory. What is the inventory value at the end of the year?

Answer: {2:NUMERICAL:=2057.12:0}

generalfeedback.text:
Price per unit under periodic weighted average cost:
= Total cost /(opening quantity + total quantity received)
= ($300 × 10) + ($250 × 12) + ($200 × 6) / (0 + 10 + 12 + 6)
= $257.14 per unit.
Closing inventory of 8 units (10 + 12 – 8 + 6 – 12) × $257.14 = $2,057.12

questiontext.text:
Duchovny's draft financial statements show a profit of $8,000 for the year ended 30 June 20X4.
Duchovny's inventories at 30 June 20X4 were measured at $25,000. This includes a quantity of product H, with a cost of $3,000, which is now obsolete. Duchovny expects to be able to sell product H during the year ended 30 June 20X5 for $1,200.
Which TWO of the following statements are correct?
(Examiner's report, September 2022 to August 2023)

generalfeedback.text:
The first option is correct. Inventories should be measured at the lower of cost and net realisable value in accordance with IAS 2 Inventories. This is an application of prudence as assets must not be overstated.
The fourth option is correct. Inventories must be adjusted by $1,800 ($3,000 - $1,200) to reflect the lower net realisable value of product H:
Dr Cost of sales (Statement of profit or loss)
Cr Inventories (Statement of financial position)
The adjustment in profit or loss is a debit entry and, therefore, profit will reduce (reflects the future loss expected on the sale of inventories).
Adjusted profit for the year is calculated as follows:
Draft profit$8,000
Inventories adjustment(1,800)
$6,200
The second statement is incorrect as this does not apply the measurement criteria per IAS 2.
The third statement is incorrect. Inventories should be recorded as $23,200 ($25,000 - $1,800).

answer.text: Duchovny should write down inventories by $1,800 as an application of prudence
Duchovny will record the loss in relation to product H in his financial statements for the year ended 30 June 20X5, when they are sold
Closing inventories at 30 June 20X4 should be valued at $23,800
Duchovny's adjusted profit for the year ended 30 June 20X4 should be $6,200
